replies.author: @CrniWuk
replies.text:
@londeners3321  >>first off the only people under threat from the coronavirus are people (...)<<

First off to you, who cares? People are people and they have a right to be protected as everyone else. What you're basically saying is, they are unhealthy/elderly/what-ever, so why should I care? Another point some conservatives love to hammer down on. We can't shut down our economy to save them! Not that it's actually releveant - you will see in a minute why it's not - but it reveals a very disturbing thought. That some lives are simply are not worth to be protected. I am not sure if that is a good basis for runing a society.

>>(...) of age or basically anyone above the age of 65,<<

Actually, this is a very dangerous misconception people have when it comes to the Corona Virus. Infact it is actually dangerous for everyone. It's just not the same kind of risk. Yes 12 year old child will have a far lower risk of seeing severe issues or even dying compared to a 80 year old with breathing issues. However and this is something some people don't think about immunity would require about 70% of the population to be infected and recover. With a nation like the United States where looking at 250 Million people here. We also know that about 10-15% of all Corona cases will be severe ones. Regardless of age or conditions. So even young and healthy people can get pneumonia. Imagine  just 10% of 250 Million people ending up with pneumonia. And from a Virus that is not known. There is still a lot of variables when it comes to the afftereffects, see Long Covid, Fatigue Syndrome and many other issues. In some cases people couldn't breath normaly even months after they suffered from the infection. 

Do you really want to take this kind of healt risk for the whole nation ... because ... wearing a mask is tyranny? Because this is how some people talk.

>>you'd discover that governors such as Cuomo were stuffing people<<

We can talk about individuals and their actions during the pandemic all you want. I do not support every measure nor do I think you should stop to be critical here.

The point however is, at the end of the day, it is a pandemic and it is far more  dangerous than just the typical "flu". Look at any person who's really experienced in this kind of medical field. Look at the science behind it. The people which actually do research on this virus. They all say that it shouldn't be taken lightly. Even Goerge J Bush had decades ago the opinion that nations have to protect themself better from pandemics. 

My point is, this should be a non-partisan issue. But one side, clearly, made it into a partisan problem. Talk about idiots with democrats all you want. But when you look at it many Republicans couldn't stop to downplay this virus and gawking about how it's a lie by democrats to get Trump. And this killed people.

Heh, were that true (yeah, I'm sure he kept a bread knife, hell I do), they'd wet around the King's bed over my kitchen knives - all of which I can literally shave with.
But, the UK doesn't have such insane laws. They just object to assholes running around with knives who don't have what is considered a valid purpose, such as occupation.
And interestingly, I was never bothered beyond inspection of my 2 1/2 inch blade or my Gerber multi-tool. The Gerber's non-sheep's foot blade sucks, so I have the EDC blade for utility cutting purposes.
As a hint, used to spar with SAS and SBS forces, just for mutual fun, since we served alongside one another.
And nothing beats an ass beating like a good professional one, although we did mutually wonder who won at times, then popped off for a few pints.
The Canadians can also set quite the party table...   ;)
All enjoyed briefly my leading with my head, then they learned that Gibraltar is soft in comparison.  :P
As my cousin's goat learned the hard way, nearly knocking itself unconscious after making the mistake of butting me in the forehead.
Still, the pints were welcome and the companionship was excellent.

@docequis9796 I know this is a ancient comment, but I would like to remind you (well, anyone who's reading actually) of two things: first, It's the 1930's, government overeach just wasn't nearly as effective, you could easily own a number of weapons and nobody would be the wiser, second we had the uprising of Warsaw's ghetto in 1943, the jewish population there managed to smuggle weapons and explosives into the ghetto, however, would you know It, that wasn't nearly enough to fight back against the german war machine (they were fighting soldiers with effectively infinite ammo at that time with rifles).

As an addendum, in Brazil we had weapons and ammo pretty much unregulated since Its founding all the way to the 2000's. Between 1937 to 1945 and 1964 to 1985 the country saw very open dictadorships and people could still get weapons and ammo to attempt to face off against the regime. Suffice It to say, although there were attempts, they never even came close to ending the Estado Novo or the Military Dictadorship, that's both because people are willing to live under said dictadorship reluctantly - if not willingly - and cannot realitically form an effective resistance (simple question, how would 300+ million people purchase sufficient ammo to fight the 1.3 million soldiers of the US and their military assets? It's a simple accounting issue, you need income to form a freaking army that's capable of winning a mordern military while also fullfilling basic needs such as housing and food; your conservative ideals have this problem economics all the time, and that without even counting the fact that Federal Premium Ammunition or Winchester wouldn't be all that willing to even sell ammuntion to a rebel group).

replies.author: @Clean97GTI
replies.text:
@SkadooHusky I suppose pointing out that the Nazis were intent on holding large portions of Europe as their own territory and intended the systematic slaughter of millions of citizens, and the USA didn't, hasn't crossed your mind?
The difference was intent and the willingness to achieve goals. The USA had no intention of committing genocide and claiming Iraq or Vietnam as its own. If that had been the case, you'd probably find the conduct of US forces to be much different than it was. In fact, we did see the US commit similar atrocities in Vietnam. The My Lai massacre comes to mind. And that's the crux of it; how far are you willing to go in achieving your objectives? The US could have been far more brutal than it was. European powers did horrendous things during their colonial years, and the US could have taken that route and held not only military supremacy, but total civil supremacy. 
But it's not like the USA was easy on anyone. Take a look at the outcomes of major battles and offensives in Vietnam. After 1968, the Viet Cong was all but wiped out. They initiated the Tet Offensive and got slaughtered. It was a bloodbath that the VC never really recovered from. After 1968, Viet Cong never managed to launch another major offensive. The NVA did, but even then, they understood that they weren't going to be successful  unless they could match American military power, which rarely ever happened. The casualty figures tell the tale. The US military could damn near march with impunity anywhere in S. Vietnam. They could launch incursions at will into North Vietnam. By 1968, the US had air superiority, with the only real danger coming from AA guns and missiles on the ground. North Vietnamese jets didn't engage directly too much in the latter half of the war, because they lost on a regular basis.

I guess the point is that while insurgents make the news, when you ask the commanders on the ground what their concerns are, it's the things that can actually impede them in their tasks. US commanders in Iraq and Afghanistan didn't resort to brutal tactics against civilians, because they needed the cooperation of the civilians. That wouldn't have helped achieve their goals. Insurgents are a problem, but they're a manageable problem. Guys with rifles can impede your progress, but they can't fuck up your whole day like an enemy company with tanks can. That's the difference between guerrilla fighters and organized armies.

replies.text:
@SkadooHusky The military isn't just the hardware, it's the logistics. Getting ahold of an enemy tank is great, but not if you can't fuel the thing or get more ammo for it.
But the original point is that militias and civilian resistance don't really measure up well against trained, disciplined, well-supplied armies. From the early days of the American Revolution when militia fled again and again in the face of the English army, until the Continental Congress paid for a professional army. The Viet Cong essentially stopped functioning as an organized militia/guerrilla force after 1968, and the NVA grew as a result. The Mujahadeen in Afghanistan in the late 1970s-Early 1980s were getting slaughtered wholesale and couldn't stop the Soviets until, mysteriously, US weaponry started showing up on the battlefields. The Soviets had a lock on the border and could stop most weapons shipments coming in from Pakistan until Stinger missiles arrived. 
But even then, the Soviets didn't lose militarily. They gave up because their economy was in a tailspin. Just a couple years after they left Afghanistan after a ten year occupation, the USSR collapsed and the Berlin wall came down.
Histrionics paints a rosy picture of the common man in his valiant struggle against the government oppressor. History tells us that the valiant common man, usually gets killed in that struggle, in greater number than government oppressors.

replies.author: @SovietButcher
replies.text:
Well, the Polish Home Army was a thorn in Nazi Germany's side; just a thorn though.

To all the people telling Mike McKeen to google the French Resistance and so on. I don't think you grasp the scope of the Resistance movements throughout Europe. Take the Home Army for instance. They were an underground political and military organisation composed of ex-military and ex-politicians/intelligentsia (4 times as big as the French Resistance with 400 000 people in it; while the French only had close to 100 000. People that joined the FFI passed 1944 are opportunists that seized the moment to deal with personal grievances). The fighters were either ex-military or trained by ex-military; which in turn made them into a rather useful para-military group. However, they never actually took back any territory, it was not possible. Their major accomplishments are mostly hindering the German logistics, taking out key German operators and passing on intel. Let's not forget that once WWII was over, the Home Army was dissolved except for the Cursed Soldiers. Another resistance movement that did little to hinder the U.S.S.R (not through lack of trying). You guys are acting as if these resistance movements were decisive for the victory and kept Nazi Germany from occupying the land (which is the point being made by the pro-2A people) which is UTTERLY FALSE.


The French Resistance is an even worse example. Composed mostly of young men and women that had NO military training, had NO hierarchy and were parceled into little groups usually with different political ideologies that would rarely work together for a common goal. Again, not a single resistance movement actually did anything when it comes to the occupation; they gathered intel, killed German key operators and sabotaged their logistical lines. At no point did they take back any land, at no point were they an actual threat to the occupation of their country. So no, armed civilians would and can not take back land. 


You're all some wannabe minutemen, not understanding the complexity of war and the logistics war entails. As a civilian (even as an ex-military civilian) you do not have the logistics to confront a stronger enemy head on. You cannot coordinate attacks, you cannot resupply your lines properly, you cannot actually hold a position. You could have all the guns in the world but if your army fails and is disbanded, you're left alone with your group of friends. What will you do then? Have 20 men attack a garrison to take back a city? Try it, odds are you'll end up dead of tortured for information. You're going to sabotage them? Sure, do so; however, if the occupying force doesn't have another enemy it's fighting, you're not doing anything really. You're just hindering your own by damaging infrastructure they are using. Now If there still is a war going on; the most useful thing a resistance movement can do is intel gathering. Not fighting, not sabotaging, but intel gathering. 


All this to say you guys are using TERRIBLE examples to prove your point. 
The original point made by these pundits is this: "Armed civilians would deter an army from invading/deter a dictator from taking power."
The arguments you are making by commenting "google the (insert country here) resistance is this: "Resistance movements existed, never took back any land, and were more of a support unit for other nation's armies."
The Historical facts are that not a single resistance movement in the world has achieved independence alone. If they achieved it, it was with the help of a foreign government/army. 


Now that you've read (or not) this comment, you may now disregard it and keep believing that you're Rambo and that if ever your country were to be invaded you'll single-handedly retake all of the country with the help of your semi-automatic rifle,

replies.author: @Clean97GTI
replies.text:
@owen-nd7om I'm pointing out that the beloved militiaman or partizan or guerilla or freedom fighter or resistance member, isn't going to put up much of a defense against a well-supplied, professional army. This notion of the small insurgent force winning, is the exception, not the rule. And the examples typically thrown out like the Minutemen from the American Revolution, the Mujahadeen of Afghanistan, the Viet Cong, generally lack context. They hardly ever achieved lasting victories without support. The Russians were effectively dominant in Afghanistan until the Mujahadeen started receiving real support and supplies from the USA. They had no ability to counter the Russian helicopters, until the CIA started slipping them Stinger missiles. The Viet Cong were known to use long bamboo poles to counter American helicopters. They'd pop out of the ground, lob the poles at the rotors in the hopes of causing enough damage to force the helicopter to land. This ignores the fact that American helicopters had machine gunners watching for that very thing, and as a result, bamboo poles didn't work all that well.

If you feel you should fight in your hypothetical scenario, then by all means do so. Just be aware that your actions are more of a nuisance and a delaying tactic. You're hoping for a political shift, not a rout.

replies.author: @spvillano
replies.text:
@paulbrower the only reason that the Bolsheviks gained any support was due to food shortages caused by actions in WWI.
Happy, well fed people don't over throw their governments, but unhappy and being starved of food will make one decidedly unhappy do get angry enough to topple their own governments, with history being replete with examples.

Now, I grew up until I was 9 in a Jewish neighborhood, both observant and non-observant. I can still track a fair amount of a conversation in Yiddish. It doesn't require strict observance to ethical laws in a book, as long as one's learned those ancient lessons and applies them.
If my neighbor is low on food, I know that some decision likely was less than optimal and they're experiencing a shortfall - usually by selling their food stamps. I get the same amount as they do (yes, more than one neighbor has come up short), I do exercise good stewardship and literally maintain a pantry with two to three months of staples. Largely, because I'm lazy and only visit the supermarket twice a month at most and I quite enjoy a wide variety of foods - especially my greens.
So, I just tell them "oh, go shopping and enjoy!". Gonna have to pick up another bag of potatoes, gave the last few to a neighbor, but not a biggie, got other root veggies in stock and even instant mash and au gratin crap mix as a rare comfort food. And I also bake my own bread on occasion.
That provides a good example for those who hadn't learned those skills and as I've said to many a man, a man isn't worth much if he can't repair things around the house, keep the house clean and feed himself.
Something important, as I lost my wife of over 41 years several years back, but I believe in learning and paid attention to when mom was cooking and sewing (albeit, at a far lower skill level for sewing).
But, every day, my goal is to learn at least one new thing and am always willing to share that knowledge.

In my previous apartment, we had a Synagogue next door. One source of anger for me was that they felt the need to have armed security during services.
Nobody that wishes to worship peacefully should ever have to feel that need! That isn't what I served over 28 years of my life in military defense of! And that wasn't necessary in Qatar or even Iran. 
Yes, most Americans don't realize that there is an ancient and sizable Jewish community happily living in Iran. Met a fair number over the years as they traveled, usually worked some history into the conversation, even Esther. Surprised a fair number, that an American knew history and certain holy books, but as I said, learn something new every day.
One of the easiest ways to turn a potential adversary into a friend and the easiest, not being judgemental, but accepting them based upon their own value systems.

author: @Derek-d5097
text:
As a Turkish citizen, I do not see the logic behind the idea of preventing a tyrannical government by having large number of guns. The weapons may be an advantage to fight against a tyrannical regime, but it certainly is not enough to win against the oppressor.

Here in my country, people can get different kinds of weapons if they like. They can get handguns, hunting rifles or shotguns, they can even get an AK-47 if they live in rural areas. By U.S. and European standards, Erdogan is already an authoritarian man and the country has already turned into a tyrannical regime by having the largest number of journalists jailed, poor human rights records, poor checks and balances in the government. In other words, it is a tyrannical regime in Ben Shapiros or Ben Carsons word. Yet, the Erdogans government still has a huge number of popularities in the nation where half the country will rather die than electing another government. If the opposition groups revolt against Erdogan, it will only make his job easier to finally get rid of whatever opposition left in the country under the excuse of combating against terrorism. So, revolting against the government and shooting Erdogans men is equal to giving him a golden gift basket for their supports to help his cause.

Also, Erdogan has the control of the entire military, police-force, and intelligence agencies. However, if the opposition groups start a civil-war, for example, then he may not even bother to mobilize the army but rather he can give weapons to his supporters and send them to fight against the oppositions. Then, he can simply justify his actions by saying to the world that there are uprising events happening because of the opposition groups and he will remove them to protect the democracy from collapsing. So, tyrannical governments do not acknowledge themselves as they are tyrannical and claim that they are functioning democracies, republics, or something else even though they are not.

In short, there is no ultimate solution to stop a tyrannical government from gaining power because the guns which are used to prevent a tyranny can easily be used as a back bone for tyrannical regimes to rise at the same time. Look at the Syria for example, for a time the opposition groups were winning when they were supplied from other countries but once the Russia, a professional military were involved in the conflict, they began to retreat to the point that they lost all the chances of winning.

To prevent a tyrannical government, one needs more than just guns. They need a strong public popularity, allies from outside that will support and supply the oppositions against the tyrannical government, advanced weapons to combat against the government's armored divisions, air and sea dominance, professional people who knows how to fight or how to survive against the odds such as sickness, starvation, dehydration, physiological traumas or PTSD, and low morale. If an opposition group lacks any of these to fight against tyranny and rely only to their guns, that means they lost the war before even it begins.

@kimdirkim12 You misunderstood the situation on what is going on in here. The purpose of the comment was not to compare the Turkey with Nazi Germany but to show why an unpopular uprising in an authoritarian nation, such as Turkey, will unlikely be successful to topple the regime even though the oppositions have access to firearms. 

The country is like Iran you ask? No. Not yet...  But the reason why it did not turn out like Iran yet is not because Erdogan cannot do that. replies.author: @1111Tactical
replies.text:
It's critical in the first stages of insurgency, a concept no one here including Three Arrows has a grasp on. You need a militia to destabilize the government, and build enough control and seize enough from the enemy military to then snow ball into something closer to a conventional army by taking over facilities with stuff like tanks, as well as taking individuals to provide training or become potent enough to inspire defectors. Then it snowballs into an actual army that  is rising in strength as the establishment's army is falling in strength. There is then a turning point where the resistance army becomes stronger, than a full ousting I conducted. That first stage needs armed militias. A revolution is not guaranteed success, the more well equipped the starting militia is, the higher the chance that the snowball effect needed to ultimately win will work. 

Due to the second amendment, the American populace currently has the highest chances of completing this cycle in such a scenario if it ever arose, which  I hope it never has to.


The government having drones/tanks/gunships doesn't make any of this impossible as we see with the US and allies quagmires in the Middle East. 


Abrams tanks can't enforce curfews.
Predator drones can't maintain rule of law.

replies.author: @Derek-d5097
replies.text:
@1111Tactical While I understand  your point, I must say I am not really sold into your hypothesis of snowball effect of toppling a government with militia. Here is why:

If I understand correctly, then your hypothesis works like this: 
First, have a well-armed people. Then, start training to become a commendable force against government troops.
Second, use that militia to take over military facilities to obtain advance weapons such as tanks. Then, the militia will turn itself to an army.
Third, attack government head on and topple it.

Your hypothesis lacks two most essential key elements for a revolution. One is the public popularity. In order for your hypothesis to become reality, pretty much all people in the nation needs to stand behind you on toppling a government and needs to support your cause. However, assuming from the start that majority of the country fights with you will be an unwise strategy for you to take because some of them will not. People may not see that fighting to topple the government is justified for damages that they will receive as a result of retaliation. Also, there is a probability that armed militia may decide to stand with the government instead of you due to seeing you as a terrorist. So, in a way, you need to clarify what guarantee you have that armed-militias will stand behind you to topple the regime and not going to stand with the government. Because if it turns out that they are well-armed but they are not supporting your cause, then you will have even a bigger problem to deal with for both fighting against the government and its supporters. So, it would be better for you to make sure that you have strong public popularity at first then forming an armed-militia. You should not assume that they will fight for you regardless just because it is tyrannical. The reason is, they may be okay living under such conditions. Russia is an authoritarian, yet a large amount of people are somewhat okay under living it. Syria is an authoritarian, yet its people are also okay under the leadership of Assad. Turkey is somewhat authoritarian, but half the country prefers to live in this condition then otherwise.

Second, your hypothesis assumes that government will not take major actions to prevent such uprising from the start. However, in reality that is not the case. You need to hit multiple military facilities and not just one in order to make a major impact. The problem is though such coordinated attacks require communications throughout the country. But a tyrannical government will have easy access to listen private communications between these people. They can suspect from the start if there are large people gatherings are happening throughout the country and for that they can cut off all communications between you and your friends. By the time you realize what is happening, a majority of your friends may end up arrested for charges of terrorism (it would be a legitimate charge because you indeed try to topple a government after all). Besides, assume for a minute you are winning and government is losing to hold its territories. In this case, governments do not just sit there and accept the defeat. Instead, they ask help from their allied nations to intervene in such conflict. Syria is a good example for this. When the opposition were supplied from their allies and Syria government were losing control in some territories, they asked help from Russia who turned the tide on their favors. So, governments do not just sit and let you guys make plans to overthrow their regime and can arrest you for the suspicion of your actions of treason and terrorism in the first stage which makes it difficult for your snowball effect to take its course.

Try to apply your hypothesis into this video for example. Do you see that Jews were toppling the government and winning against the Nazis? If yes, then you made a mistake somewhere. Jews in Germany were approximately 500,000 people in a nation with 70 million and Germany prior to WWII was pretty anti-Semitic towards to Jews. So, if we apply your hypothesis into this scenario, then it is difficult that snowball effect would take its course because there were more Nazi supporters than the entire Jewish population in the nation. In this case, if Jews would attack the military facilities to capture the Panzers then they would likely be pushed back by the armed Nazi supporters who would label them as traitors. As the video explains that Nazis were okay with their own supporters for having access to firearms. Thus, if there was a Jew that was willing to shoot a SS personnel, then you should assume that there would be two more Nazi supporters who would be willing to shoot that Jew before the SS and SA showed up with its full force. Also, any kind of communication to capture the military facilities will be exposed from the start because Hitler made it okay for government to listen private communications among people. In this case, your hypothesis seems to fail to meet its criteria in the first and second stage which makes it very difficult for Jews to topple the regime.

I also tried to apply your hypothesis into my own country. It still failed to meet the criteria because we have access to firearms (not as easily as in US but it is possible), but there is no strong public popularity to support to topple the regime and instead half the country would be willing to support the authoritarian government from collapsing by arming themselves against the opposition groups. Attacking to a military facility and killing military or police personnel will also be considered as the highest treason that will be condemned even by the opposition groups. Something like that would justify the government's respond to get rid of any strong opposition even further because they would have a legitimate reason to do so at that point. So, in my case, it failed at the first step to create your snowball effect because not many people would risk themselves to topple a government by destroying their own country in the process if some of them think they live better under an authoritarian regime. Thus, your hypothesis needs to be a little more specific and more applicable to the real world events and not just on paper as hypothetical scenarios.

replies.author: @Derek-d5097
replies.text:
@1111Tactical  "Due to the second amendment, the American populace currently has the highest chances of completing this cycle in such a scenario if it ever arose, which  I hope it never has to."

After my observations of the people in U.S., I can say that they do not. I am aware of your militia groups and preppers (I guess that is what you people call). I must say I am not really impressed with their performance of overthrowing a government if it comes to that. The reason you should be skeptical of those groups because the order they will install after they topple a tyrannical government (assuming they can at the first place and have strong allies from outside world that will supply them) may not be better than the previous tyrannical government. So, I would not recommend for you to put all your eggs (all your hopes of a successful revolution) into this one basket (trusting militias alone because you never know. Perhaps they acknowledged that the government is not as tyrannical as other people accusing of or government may form its own militia groups from its supporters as counter measures).

"The government having drones/tanks/gunships doesn't make any of this impossible as we see with the US and allies quagmires in the Middle East."

The low performance of US in this region is the result of the mismanagement of your leaders for failing to understand the reality of the situation. You are not just fighting against the enemy, you are trying to build a pro U.S. government in Iraq with no cultural similarities. In short, you are trying to build a state from the start but you should have realized that state-building missions take decades of work and a lot of resources. You guys entered the region for toppling the regime and wanted to withdraw as fast as possible but the thing you did not realize is that establishing a pro-U.S. government and withdrawing from the region as fast as possible are things that cannot happen at the same time. On that sense, one can assume that you guys would do a better job on defeating the insurgents if you just simply annex the entire country because only then it would be your main problem to deal with. But instead you did not want to deal with it as your main problem and just wanted to get out from the region the moment Saddam's government collapsed. You can say that drones, tanks, gunships are doing their job pretty good against insurgents. Your government at that time miscalculated badly which they thought they were going to get out of that region in just a couple of years instead of acknowledging that they were going to stay there for a pretty long time. You also need to understand that people love freedom but they do not want to live in a anarchist type of freedom where everyone is for himself. They need freedom but they also need food, jobs, and feeling to secure because otherwise freedom alone does not justify the costs of that freedom. People cheered when Saddam was gone but now some of them wants him back because the freedom they received did not justify the costs of living in constant instability.

"Predator drones can't maintain rule of law."

No they do not maintain rule of law but that is the idea. They do not have to. A tyrannical regime does not need to follow the rule of law and they can bend the rules according to their own views by either changing the rule or changing their interpretation of those laws. Those things are pretty common in authoritarian regimes where they tend to change the laws according to their own desires. The problem is how are you going to identify it? Perhaps the government is making some genuine changes to improve the living conditions or perhaps they are indeed trying to change the laws in their favor to gain more power. This is the reason that it is difficult for people to rise against government because some may see those changes as reasonable while others may see it as the rise of tyranny, and for that, a major uprising against the government where most of the people united as one is very rare.

"Abrams tanks can't enforce curfews."

No they can't enforce curfews. That is why governments rely on their supporters in those territories to force their rules upon nation. It might be strange for you people but not many people are worried to live in an authoritarian government if they live better under its rule such as high paying jobs for their families and increase of their wealth. Desperation forces people to take desperate measures for not wanting to lose what little they had before that government. For that, you may end up in a situation to fight against both government troops and its supporters who are enforcing the government's rule over territories to protect their gains if you spend more time on arming the population then actually convincing them to support your cause to topple it at the first place.

replies.author: @Donbd83
replies.text:
Small arms are very effective against a bigger military power. Who won Vietnam the US with all its planes, tanks, napalm, agent orange and burning of villages and still they couldn't take and hold the land against farmers armed with small arms. During Desert Storm the entire American military along with NATO couldn't hold Baghdad with its superior numbers and technology and still couldn't wrestle control of it from civilians armed with small arms and improvised weaponry, these same civilians beat the shit out of Russia as well. America defeating Britain the most powerful military in the world at the time with only 3% of the active public resisting, the worse thing Britain could of done was try and use violence to subdue any descent as that just rallies more to the cause.

replies.author: @Derek-d5097
replies.text:
@Donbd83 "Who won Vietnam the US with all its planes, tanks, napalm, agent orange and burning of villages and still they couldn't take and hold the land against farmers armed with small arms"

You mean the farmers who were supplied by the North Vietnam who was also well supported by the Soviet Union and China with advanced weapons and had decades of combat experience fighting against French and Japanese? Granted, I guess you could make an argument from that but it is only the tip of the iceberg and a lot of other factors occurred in that war for the U.S. poor track record against Vietnamese. To stop the Vietnam insurgents in the South Vietnam, the North Vietnam needed to be persuaded to stop sending their insurgents and weapons through the border. The problem is though, U.S. never tried to invade the North Vietnam due to U.S. administration feared that both Soviet Union and China would also join the fight against U.S. and instead U.S. military was instructed to launch bombing campaigns in North Vietnam such as Operation Rolling Thunder. However, the military was strictly forbidden to bomb important places such as Surface-to-air missile (SAM) fields due to fear of killing Soviet "instructors."  Also, U.S. air force was forbidden to bomb North Vietnam airfields which caused for U.S. not to obtain air dominance over the region and picking targets with low importance in North Vietnam. So, in a nutshell, you are trying to force North Vietnam into submission to stop supporting South insurgents but at the same time you do not want to invade the North and rely only on bombing the territories with low importance. How do you expect that U.S. would achieve victory in this situation against Vietnamese? Short answer; You don't, because Vietnam war was a huge political mess between the military and administration over how to achieve victory in the region. That is why, saying that farmers with small arms won the Vietnam war is very misleading because we know at this point that those farmers had more than just small arms including, SA-2 guideline SAM missiles, Mig-21 jets with their air-to-air missiles, thousands of RPG-7, thousands of Soviet AA guns, etc.

"During Desert Storm the entire American military along with NATO couldn't hold Baghdad with its superior numbers and technology and still couldn't wrestle control of it from civilians armed with small arms and improvised weaponry"

I assume you confused the Desert Storm operation with Iraq war because that operation's main objective was to force Saddam to abandon his campaign against Kuwait. The main objective was never to capture the Baghdad but rather to free Kuwait from Iraqi troops. For this, both U.S. and NATO achieved both of its objective by removing all Iraqi troops from Kuwait and forcing Saddam to submit for a cease fire. It is actually interesting you mentioned the Operation Desert Storm because after that operation ended, there were uprising events occurred both North and South of Iraq against Saddam's tyrannical regime and both U.S. and NATO was almost certain that his government would collapse because at least half of the nation's cities were occupied by the rebels. However, it turned out that the opposite happened because in less than 2 months, Saddam's forces crushed the rebels first in the South which turned the tide to his favor. He basically gave the order to his party officials either to kill or be killed at the hands of rebels. Government forces used missiles, artillery, helicopters, tanks, and chemical weapons against the rebels to force them to surrender. After the South region was under the control of the government once again, he began to launch attacks against Kurdish militia in the North. Iraqi army helicopters and tanks bombarded the cities and gave order to Kurdish population of Kirkuk city to leave if they wanted to survive. At the end, almost all militia that were fighting against Saddam was either killed, taken prisoner, or fled to surrounding countries. Approximately more than 450,000 Kurds ended up in our borders as refugees who fled from Iraq for their cities being demolished and the fear of retaliation from government troops. It turned out that militias with small arms were not be able to stop Iraqi government troops with T-62 tanks, and Mil Mi-24 helicopters, and chemical weapons when they were not supported or supplied by other nations such as U.S. and other NATO nations. 

"these same civilians beat the shit out of Russia as well"

When did that happen exactly?

replies.author: @Derek-d5097
replies.text:
@Donbd83 "America defeating Britain the most powerful military in the world."

That is actually debatable. It is not up to debate that the Royal Navy was the most powerful naval force during that time due to Britain being an Island nation. However, some historians would disagree that Britain had the most powerful army or ground troops and would argue that either French or Prussians should had that title for having better training, discipline, logistics, sizes, and their records of warfare. You also did not mention that Americans had tons of international support such as from Spain, French, and Dutch where as the Britain had almost no support to fight against the Patriots in the colonies. It is difficult to claim they would won against the Britain without any support from their allies on providing them with money and supply of weapons because it is known that French Navy and their military officers contributed a lot for the fight against the British. It is also known that despite Britain having a considerable military power, they lost quite a bit of wars during that time and American Revolutionary war was just one of them. Moreover, Britain did not want to continue to fight against Americans who were both receiving thousands of foreign troops and supplies from their allied nations because colonies did not have a big importance for Britain compared to other regions such as India. Therefore, sending another army to colonies even after they were defeated was meaningless because the support for such a war was pretty much gone.  

"at the time with only 3% of the active public resisting"

Source please.

"So yes history shows that small arms are able to stave off larger and better equipped militaries."

I mean you can make the argument if you like but again, your examples are only the tip of the iceberg in very complex situations and when we look at deeply for each of these examples, it is becoming difficult to say if your historical evidence are good representations of what actually happened in history in order to support your claim. Because if your evidence are not historically accurate to support your argument, then you need to start from all over again to strength your claim more. Otherwise, you need to abandon your argument completely if you are unable to increase its strength by finding accurate evidence.

replies.text:

replies.author: @Derek-d5097
replies.text:
@Donbd83 "So history sides with me on this, that you can give a force small weapons and with those weapons they can defeat superior forces as they already possess the most powerful thing needed to fight and that is the will, they tried to do this in Vietnam break their will  but you cannot break someone who has nothing to lose they essentially don't give a fuck."

If we change the definition of small weapons and put the heavy and advance weapons into the small category, then it is correct to assume that history sides with you. But, that is not the case. Also, you are agreeing that if you give advance weapons for people to fight, then you can increase your probabilities of victory? If you look at the first comment, then you will see that I agree with this notion at the first place. I already explained that small weapons can have an advantage but you need more and more and more... For example, you need strong public popularity, allies from outside that will support and supply you, and need to have an access to advance weapons. That is the reason Vietnamese won the war against the French and U.S. because it fits all these criteria that they had a strong public popularity to Ho Chi Minh's regime, they had allies such as Soviet Union and China which provided them with advanced weapons, and they know the terrain well enough to use to their advantage. If all these conditions were met, then there is a strong possibility that insurgents can win against the government with heavy weapons. Soviet-Afghan war also fits to this description as well. The Mujaheddin's fight against the Soviets was recognized by many other Muslim countries, they received heavy weapons from other developed nations as well as a great number of fighters from other Muslim countries, and they knew how to use the terrain as well. However, 1991 uprisings in Iraq did not fit to this criteria because Iraq militia did not have the support from outside world that would support and supply them against Saddam's forces. The will is something that motivates people to fight but you cannot win a war against a foe only with the will alone because they still possess the most essential thing in the world and that is their lives. Not many people would like to risk their lives and die for a lost cause. That was the reason why the militias in Iraq decided to escape rather than risking to lose the only thing they had left with against Saddam's heavy weapons. It is a good thing to assume that the will would be enough to gain victory but that is not what is happening in real life.

"Britain was defeated by logistics and the one thing these invading countries need to occupy and continue occupation and that is money and support of its people. I am willing to bet that had the Zulu's been given small arms in their defense against the British the British wouldn't be in Africa now, they still brag about winning battles armed with firearms versus men with swords and shields, give those same people firearms and the British would go crying back to England like the pussies they are."

Correct. So you are understanding that Logistics was one of the main factors that caused the Britain to lose in the colonies. Therefore, it is more accurate to say "patriots with the help of their allies who provided with weapons, troops, and money managed to hold on against the Britain until a point they gave up on fighting" instead of saying "Americans won against Britain only with a small arms alone" because that is not historically accurate on what actually happened. You say that, only 3% (still waiting for that source) of the people fought against the British. Now imagine, what would happen if the 70% of people wanted to stay loyal to Britain? Do you still see a victory against the British if patriots did not have enough public popularity or not enough support from their allies on troops, navy power, or weapons? Highly unlikely.

For Zulu, It would increase their chances a little bit but they would still need support from a powerful nation such as France or Dutch, then it would increase their chances of a victory against the British. There are times when small weapons are simply not enough to gain advantage. Assuming that Zulu had access to small weapons such as muskets or pistols, they would still be in a disadvantaged position because the Britain had already possessed heavy weapons such as cannons, rockets, Gatling  guns at that time. Therefore, I wouldn't have been so comfortable for a Zulu victory just because they possessed small arms because remember Britain fought against other powerful nations who had same type of weapons and won against formidable opponents such as Napoleon. Even we managed to defeat them in Gallipoli campaign, but overall they took over the rest of the Middle Eastern territories (except Anatolia) from us at the same time.

replies.author: @norwegianboyee
replies.text:
@Doruk Dalgun
I read all your comments. They are excellently written and you seem like a very well educated and interesting Turkish individual. Your knowledge about warfare, insurgency, politics and history is admirable to read. 
I am curious and would like to know what is your stance on Erdogan. You discuss a lot about how armed uprising against your country's authoritarian government is hopeless as there is approximately 50% of people in the country who support and would be willing to fight for his continued rule in the case of armed opposition. He also appears to have the military under his control (Unless some high ranking members of the military plan a coup?) so regime change appears to be, for the time being: impossible. 
Do you wish for your country to become democratic like it pretends to be in order to garner support from the Western world? Do you wish for dictators like Erdogan to disappear from Turkey? I live in Norway, one of the most democratic countries in the world. So i simply cannot fathom how life under tyranny must be. But like you say, it is not bad for everyone. Some people live comfortably in the system because of their privileged position, or they simply enjoy the stability that the dictatorship brings. Even if they wish to have more freedom to express themselves, when the choice is between retaining the stability of the country or to risk everything in ensuing chaos and death in the hope of regime change. It is obvious which path most people in the middle and high class would take. Only people who'se life are already miserable such as lower class peasants, poor or oppressed people would want to solve the problem by armed opposition. After all, once a country has settled in a authoritarian government without democratic laws or checks and balances. It is very difficult to change. You'd end up with a one-party rule like The People's Republic of China or one man dictatorship like Syria. Unless special circumstances come into play. Foreign invasion, military coup, power vacuum... Internal change is much more difficult. And even if it is successful, such as the French revolution. It might just turn the country into yet another dictatorship again. 
It truly is a sad world. The only thing i want is for a state that protects the rights of individuals, unfortunately this kind of state appears to be a rarity in this world. I feel grateful, but at the same time sad and shameful that i was born in a country which protects the liberty of man so well. Yet cannot do the same for outsiders who live in flawed countries.

replies.author: @Derek-d5097
replies.text:
@norwegianboyee For your question. Do I want the country to pretend like it is a functioning democracy to the Western World? No, I do not because it only means the current status quo will continue as it did for almost a decade. At this point, the status quo is no longer enough to continue to this circus. Technically speaking, we are a constitutional republic but it does not mean anything if there is little to no checks and balances in the nation. So in a nutshell, I saw the Erdogan and his party's rise and I have a feeling that I will see its fall too, However, I have little confidence that things will be better once Erdogan is gone. The reason is if he is somehow removed from power or choose to live the office willingly, then the next person who comes to power will almost be same as Erdogan himself and rule the nation according to his style. So, because of this I do not have faith in Turkey to become a stable and a functioning republic in this century.


Do I want people like Erdogan to disappear from country? In short, yes I do. The reason is that Erdogan is not Putin or Xi Jinping. He is someone who wants to act like Putin but has the intelligence of Trump. I believe you have a good reasoning at this point why things would be better a little bit if he is out of the picture. However, the problem is that if the country becomes a functioning republic, then it is almost certain that people like Erdogan will always come to power. Unfortunately, that is just how things are working in nations such as Turkey. You can choose to become a secular authoritarian nation which will prevent people like Erdogan from achieving power indefinitely but at the same time it will not be a stable government and will receive backlash from other nations including the west. On the other hand, if you choose to become a functioning republic with fair elections instead than it is almost certain that people like Erdogan will come to power and they will use their public popularity to achieve even more power and become another authoritarian conservative regime again. We are back to square one. In a way, both options seem to lead to an authoritarian government because overall public does not have interest on ruling themselves without interfering others personal life. Also, I am not sure too if something like that is possible in Turkey where the conservative religious and secular side can live in harmony because the life styles of these people are overwhelmingly different.

replies.author: @Derek-d5097
replies.text:
@ffryan Vietnam war was explained above to Donbd83 that Vietnamese had way more than small arms of AK-47s and rocket launchers. To stop the Vietcong, the North Vietnam needed to be taken care of but that was something Johnson administration did not want to do to begin with. They had advanced weapons given to them by their allies such as Soviet Union and China to counter the U.S. and South Vietnamese troops. Soviets deployed thousands of Surface-to-air (SAM) rockets against the U.S. air force which caused them not to obtain the air dominance over the region. Also, U.S. administration put lots of restrictions over the military such as not to attack North Vietnamese airfields. Here is the situation, one side (U.S. military) was strictly prohibited to launch a major offense where as the other side (North Vietnam and Soviets) was almost free to engage any enemy military force. Besides, U.S. military did not even try to invade the North Vietnam due to the fear of Soviet Union and China joining to the fight with full force. Your government created its own defeat by not willing to take the necessary measures to stop the enemy from the start. That is why, the chances for a U.S. victory was doomed from the very beginning. Even today in Afghanistan, U.S. military is heavily restricted to do their job properly. You ask why the Superpower nation had poor results against the insurgents with small arms in this past decade? Ask your current and past administrations. Nation-building missions take decades of work and billions of dollars if not trillion. You guys were mistaken to think that you were going to pull out from the region the moment you toppled the Taliban regime. The reality was that you were going to stay in that country for a couple of decades at least and I believe you guys are finally realizing this harsh truth.


As for the Afghanistan, Soviet troops occupied pretty much all important urban cities in the country until the western nations began to supply them with advance weapons. Soviet Air forces managed to occupy the entire Kabul city alone until the ground troops showed up with full force. Stingers, for example, are the most popular weapons in social media but they had more than that. Mujaheddin had access to advanced heavy weapons such as anti-air and anti-tank once the other nations were persuaded to support them against the Soviets. Also, many other nations such as Pakistan, Saudi Arabia, U.S., Turkey, and even China financially supported to Mujaheddin with money and troops against the Soviets. It turned out that small weapons of AK-47 was not strong enough to penetrate the T-62 armor or Mi 24 helicopters. Here is the funny thing though, the Communist government in Afghanistan was going to fail regardless because it was not popular and as soon as the Soviet troops withdrew from the region, the government would collapse almost instantly. The west could achieve victory in Afghanistan by pretty much not doing anything whereas the entire damage bill would go to the Soviet Union but that is not what happened in real life.

replies.author: @initiatinreallife
replies.text:
That is actually incorrect. Nazi Germany of course employed the aesthetic of the traditional family. But they did very much seek to dismantle it or at least that which really makes the traditional family, that being support and loyalty that cannot be controlled by the state. The traditional family can't really exist under fascism because under fascism the state also wants to raise the children. They can't leave that to the family because then they can't controll what the child is learning/if it's being indoctrinated correctly.

The nazis mainly did this with the Hitler Jugend and the Deutsche M盲del groups, which had a lot of their events strategically placed at times when traditionally families would be having their personal time, namely Sunday during and after church hours (because they also didn't like people going to church). They couldn't openly antagonise the traditional family model, though, because that would have lost them support among Christains and especially conservatives. 
Himmler (I think) actually at one point suggested young soldiers have children outside of their marriages in order to preserve and build the "arian master race" and there was actual some outrage from traditionalists, etc (for that and not for the mass murder and deportations that were already going on by this point...). But make no mistake, small power structures are always at odds with one big power-hungry institution, like fascism. And the traditional family is just well suited for that because when it works - and even if it doesn't- it at least temporarily creates unconditional loyalty between a small group of people and a facist dictatorship usually wants all your loyalty to go to them, not to your family.

Americans tend to think that dictatorships arise when the government becomes too much powerful, but historically it has always been the opposite. In italy the blackshirts had a free hand to kill trade unionists and socialists because the state wasn't able to provide a security for it's citizens, the fascist were using unregulated weapons (mostly obtained from WW1 veterans) to assert their own justice system. In Germany pretty much the same thing happened with the Freikorps.
In short, dictatorships are far more likely to arise thanks to paramilitary squads who can arm themselves freely

@CDexie
replies.text:
@CorwinTheOneAndOnly No, they're a subsection. Your analysis ignores the entirety of Latin America's 20th century's gallery of military dictatorships and junta's. I guess when there's unrest, there's chaos, and tyrants can/may take  advantage of that, but that's rather external, isn't it?

I wouldn't call Pinochet being installed in Chile a result of "people wanting a change for the better". Pinochet being installed in Chile is a result of US meddling and cementing their sphere of influence, i.e. maintaining the status quo.

In the same spirit, saying Franco's dictatorship in Spain was a result of people "wanting change" is so vague and reductive, it manages to be equally true and false at the same time.

Greece's military dictatorship of Metaxas in '36 wasn't the result of a people's revolution. He was given supreme powers through parliament and he seized the government.

But, what you are describing is indeed what happened to Fascist Italy and Nazi Germany. And while I wouldn't say the trend follows to Stalin, he was very loved after he came to power. So, yeah.

If we imagine a scenario where criminals could have knives, and have guns, then why are you forcing a weak, 120lb woman to prove she needs a gun, and meet those permit requirements? It should be her right to have some type of effective defence against criminals, not just pain compliance tools like civilian stun guns, or pepper spray. It just happens that a good defensive tool is also a good offensive tool, if you ban it, only criminals have it, and they use it for offense, if you don't ban it, criminals can have it and use it for offense, but then innocents can also use it for defence.

And if we imagine a scenario where the government is tyranical and we should have guns, then the government should REALLY be left out of that, the moment you give the government any control over firearms, whats stopping them from adding "just this 1 more reasonable measure" and banning any weapon that could potentially harm the government?

So i'd say: the left might give lip service to guns, just because so many people have them, but they don't actually support the reasons people have guns

replies.author: @rotwang2000
replies.text:
@falcon4186 Countries like Iraq and Libya tend to function around population groups.  They tend to run along ethnic or tribal lines, where the country's leadership either bribes loyalty or tends to oppress them.  In Iraq and Libya Saddam and Qaddafi put opposition leaders in positions of power and relied on corruption to keep them quiet.  Those they couldn't bribe like the Kurds in Iraq were the targets military campaigns and systematically isolated without roads and infrastructure to make their life anywhere from miserable to actively starving them.

In those countries having guns is fairly normal because they had endemic tribal warfare for centuries, Saddam and Qaddafi didn't oppress people like they did in 1984, trying to control every part of their existence.  In Iraq and Libya, the closer and more loyal you were to the regime, the more benefits you got, but in exchange there was no freedom of the press, there was no free vote and you had few if any rights.  Saddam and Qaddafi controlled the country, the resources and the purse, most of the money went towards them and the elites that kept them in power.

Everything was riddled with corruption, nothing could be done without having to pay off somebody.  The country was inefficient because inefficiency is the greatest tool for a dictator, the less organized everything is, the less of a threat it is to the leader.  That's why they had big armies that were useless.  On paper Iraq could have wiped the floor with Iran's army which was in a terrible state after the Shah had fallen.  They were so to speak sending kids and old men with nothing more than bad breath to fight the Iraqis and for a decade the Iraqi army failed to break Iran and it remained a stalemate.

For the average person life was not horrible, but not great either.  You could make some money, but opportunities were few and reserved for those loyal to the party.  If you were a bit too critical of the regime you might get beaten up a few times by the police, if you actively criticized the regime you might end up in a really bad place or vanish for ever.  If you belonged to a minority, things were much worse and you might live in a permanent state of insurrection.

Weapons were not a direct threat to the regime.  Leaders were, organized resistance was a threat, foreign intervention was a threat, somebody who had a power base might be a threat etc.

author: @TaraRoseGarden
text:
I'm pro-gun and even I'm disgusted by Shapiro's terrible arguments and callous attitudes. Arming the populace doesn't do much on its own. Arming the populace won't lead to an overthrow of tyranny if people have come to accept, or worse, support this tyranny. Arming the populace and overthrowing tyranny can happen, of course, but you need to actually have a populace that wants a revolution, or else it just won't happen. Hell, in Russia, it's not like the Bolsheviks revolted because they got access to guns. They revolted because general sentiment was against the government, and the mentality of revolution, of overthrowing tyranny, of doing what's necessary even if it's dangerous and illegal, that mentality had to be there first. Arming themselves was merely a tool they used to depose the Tsar, and I imagine most modern conservatives would side with a dictator over a revolution in a heartbeat.


(Also there are other reasons to have guns than overthrowing the government but the point is that the people who talk about revolution are usually the same people who would try to put it down)

replies.text: The Viet Kong are a terrible example they had the help of North Vietnam, China, the Soviet Union, North Korea and several other communist countries.

replies.author: @Songbird645
replies.text:
@themanwithnonamecalledwyat7575

As far as I know the Viet Kong got  lot of war materials from their state sponsors. They had very important state sponsor.
The Viet Kong Wikipedia article  mentions North Vietnam, China and the Soviet Union as state sponsors. The Vietnam War Wikipedia article also mentions North Korea and the Eastern Bloc countries as belligerents in this war.
The Weapons of the Vietnam War Wikipedia article writes that
"Communist forces were principally armed with Chinese and Soviet weaponry though some VC guerrilla units were equipped with Western infantry weapons either captured from French stocks during the first Indochina war, such as theMAT-49, or from ARVN units or requisitioned through illicit purchase.

In the summer and fall of 1967, all Viet Cong battalions were reequipped with arms of Soviet design such as theAK-47assault rifle and theRPG-2anti-tank weapon.Their weapons were principally of Chineseor Soviet manufacture."

Since I'm from an Eastern Bloc country I heard and read many things from this war.
For example my grandma had to work on Saturdays to aid the Viet Kong. These plus workings days called "Vietn谩mi m疟szak" were not payed because all the profit went to aid of the Viet Kongs.
If you search this term they will refer the Viet Kongs as "szabads谩茅rt k眉zd indok铆nai n茅p" and you will mostly find newspaper articles from the late 1960s bragging about how many a given factory made for the Viet Kongs.
For example the Viet Kong (and the North Vietnam) snipers used a lot of Hungarian made Mosin Nagant rifles. These rifles were made in the late 1940s and early 1950s by the very militaristic government of R谩kosi.
R谩kosi loved to waste money and resources on the military. This money and resources could have made a better life for us but they were spent on these useless weapons.. In the 1960s they gifted this to the Viet Kong. You can see these rifles in the NRA museums.
Also we made a lot of grenades (copies of the ww2 grenades) in the 1940s and gave some of it to the Viet Kongs but I haven't found any sources for that on the internet.

Soo to sum up:
The Viet Kongs had a lot of very important and powerful state sponsors who sometimes exploited their citizens to aid this war. The Viet Kongs did not fight with their own weapons. They fought with sophisticated weapons (see the Ak-47 or the RPG-2) provided by other states, mainly North Vietnam and China but had minor state sponsors like Hungary who gave them their surplus war material.

@gtamateur Also, tyrannical governments of the past don't need to disarm the citizens to take or assert control.

The classic example of Concord is a distorted reality. The colony was already under rebellion by the time the red coats were sent in to destroy munitions.

No different from US patrols finding and destroying munitions in Afghanistan or Iraq.

Hitler is often cited as having cracked down on gun ownership but this is actually a myth. Gun control was enacted by the Weimar republic to curb street violence, specifically by the Nazis and their communist foes. Under Nazi rule gun restrictions were actually LOOSENED.

replies.author: @Mahbu
replies.text:
@DimitriSlobodianyk That's a big fat. . depends.

It depends on a lot of factors.

It certainly can help a tyrannical regime if everyone is disarmed (it can also harm a tyrannical regime in that your followers aren't armed, either) but it isn't required or even a major step.

And even if the citizens are armed, it can easily fail to even slow a tyrannical regime. Take Warsaw for instance.

It was a noble stand against the Nazis. Undeniably! And some would argue they were very successful.

BUT.

You have to remember who they were opposing initially. It wasn't 1st rate or even 2nd rate troops. They were military police and support elements. As soon as actual combat personnel came into the picture, Warsaw fell almost immediately.

England and Ireland is a complex situation with a lot of nuance that can't easily be explored in the confines of a youtube comment. However, all things being equal, it wasn't so much the guns and bombs that decided everything but other factors. .  And keep in mind, the UK STILL holds Northern Ireland.

The US armed forces themselves study revolutions. Regime stability is another detail they consider. Or how close is the regime to elite infighting. Like a palace coup or an army uprising.

There's a variant of coup where the security forces lets a revolt against the regime happen by just standing aside, and then cleans out excess revolutionaries to re-establish a junta they prefer.

Functional revolutionary groups often have an existing organization. Unions, church groups, local government, an opposition party etc.

replies.author: @joshuasalem5022
replies.text:
This video isnt addressing gun rights, its about this specific question could armed Jews have prevented the holocaust?

Its worth noting perspective here, as Nazis werent cartoon villains that any reasonable person clearly should have seen as evil. The Nazi Party started out as a bunch of armed militia men who believed the same thing: that their rights were being infringed upon because of the looming threat of authoritarianism (communism in this case), and the threat of social progress turning them into a racial minority, which would lead to the degradation of their rights (which is based on the fallacy that Jews and Slavs saw Aryans the same way Aryans saw them).

I would really encourage you to look at other arguments people like Ben Shapiro make and look at it through the same critical lens Arrows does in this video.

I think every time you hear one of the conservative pundits makes a claim about what the left believes, go watch a video from a prominent left wing pundit channel (Vaush, Contrapoints, David Parkman) who gives a more accurate view of how the left sees these issues.

Myself and most people who watch those creators dont see them as righteous truth tellers, they provide perspective more than anything else.

http://research.calvin.edu/german-propaganda-archive/goeb47.htm

"England is a capitalist democracy. Germany is a socialist peoples state. And it is not the case that we think England is the richest land on earth. There are lords and City men in England who are in fact the richest men on earth. The broad masses, however, see little of this wealth. We see in England an army of millions of impoverished, socially enslaved, and oppressed people. Child labor is still a matter of course there. They have only heard about social welfare programs. Parliament occasionally discusses social legislation. Nowhere else is there such terrible and horrifying inequality as in the English slums. Those with good breeding take no notice of it. Should anyone speak of it in public, the press, which serves plutocratic democracy, quickly brands him the worst kind of rascal. They do not hesitate to make major changes in the Constitution if they are necessary to preserve capitalist democracy." - Joseph Goebbels, England's Guilt.

"If white supremacists/neo-nazis are all left-wing, why do NONE of them consider themselves such?"

There's so much wrong with this it isn't even farqing funny. And I say this as someone who spent years tracking them and other hate groups.

Firstly

A: Anybody who thinks Neo-Nazi is synonymous with White Supremacist doesn't know much. Both are utter scum, but there are plenty of White Supremacists that aren't Neo-Nazis (the old school Klan are an example. Ever try reading "The Turner Diaries?" It's hateful bilge by American Neo-Nazis fantasizing about the genocide of everybody they don't like.

Including Sheetheads.)

B: There HAVE been plenty of undeniable White Supremacist Leftists. Don't believe me?

Take a farqing look at the Rand Rebellion.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rand_Rebellion

"The racist aspect was typified by the slogan; "Workers of the world, unite and fight for a white South Africa!" and by several pogroms against blacks."

Obviously not everybody involved in the rebellion was a racist (or even a Leftist given the Reformed Chruch's influence on miners). But a number of them were.

and

C: Most people are so utterly uninformed about White Supremacist, Neo-Nazi, and Paleo-Nazi or Fascist rhetoric that they have no farqing idea what they say. And you can see that from the proliferation of fake Hitler quotes and whatnot to try and pander to different policies.

I know Mussolini defined his movement as a turn towards "the right" from where things were before, but it is mentioned a grand total of once in his ideological manifesto ("The Doctrine of Fascism") and I know it because I know where to look.

And it gets easily drowned out by Musso's discussion about the socialist roots of Fascist doctrine.

How many others can say the same?

"Why did the white supremacist Richard Spencer decide to call the movement he's attempting to build the altright and not the altleft?"

Because Spencer's a parasite who jumped onto the label after Murray Rothbart (who has his own big problems) coined it.

"The right believes in the preservation of hierarchical social relations based on class, race, and gender. Fascists embody that belief system and take it to its most extreme logical conclusion. "

Translation:

You have not the slightest farqing idea what Fascism is except what's been repeated to you at rote.

But you are going to pretend you do anyway.

No, Fascists did NOT support the *PRESERVATION* of hierarchical social relations. They were revolutionaries who favored OVERTHROWING the existing hierarchical social relations and building different ones. Mostly a hybrid national goulash of a community governed by a party.

"The Fascist negation of socialism, democracy, liberalism, should not, however, be interpreted as implying a desire to drive the world backwards to positions occupied prior to 1789, a year commonly referred to as that which opened the demo-liberal century. History does not travel backwards. The Fascist doctrine has not taken De Maistre as its prophet. Monarchical absolutism is of the past, and so is ecclesiolatry. Dead and done for are feudal privileges and the division of society into closed, uncommunicating castes. Neither has the Fascist conception of authority anything in common with that of a police ridden State." -Benito Mussolini, the Doctrine of Fascism.

http://www.worldfuturefund.org/wffmaster/Reading/Germany/mussolini.htm

Fascism defined itself as a merger of elements between the Right and the Left to create a hybrid movement that originated from Marxist Socialism, but which rejected Marxist internationalism as well as many other things.

Hence why it is also called a "Third Way" or "Third Positionism."

Hence we have Hitler's own pithy...

"In our movement the two extremes come together: the Communists from the Left and the officers and students from the Right. These two have always been the most active elements. "

"Castroy64, stop being a fucking worthless cud-chewing fool and learn something. You only live once, dipshit. "

Pot Kettle Black, mate.

Pot Kettle Black.

I want to know my enemies better than they know themselves. That is why I have labored so hard to understand the Fascism that beat up my Italian-American forebearers, as well as the Islamists and others.

Lets look at what one if not the most credited historian regarding Hitler has to say regarding this
''[Hitler] was wholly ignorant of any formal understanding of the principles of economics. For him, as he stated to the industrialists, economics was of secondary importance, entirely subordinated to politics. His crude social-Darwinism dictated his approach to the economy, as it did his entire political world-view. Since struggle among nations would be decisive for future survival, Germanys economy had to be subordinated to the preparation, then carrying out, of this struggle. This meant that liberal ideas of economic competition had to be replaced by the subjection of the economy to the dictates of the national interest. Similarly, any socialist ideas in the Nazi programme had to follow the same dictates. Hitler was never a socialist. But although he upheld private property, individual entrepreneurship, and economic competition, and disapproved of trade unions and workers interference in the freedom of owners and managers to run their concerns, the state, not the market, would determine the shape of economic development. Capitalism was, therefore, left in place. But in operation it was turned into an adjunct of the state.''
Ian Kershaw

He didn't make vague threats about his supporters being "very tough people", encourage his supporters to beat up protesters, etc. Yes, you can find examples of fed-up liberals fighting back with violent rhetoric. But nothing remotely like the language Trump is using has come from liberal Presidents (or the last few conservative Presidents!).

It's obvious that you can't answer that point. This President is wholly different in kind, and his language is very violent.

The right may not be getting more powerful; that remains to be seen. It is, however, becoming a lot more accommodating of ultra-right-wing, racist conspiracy theories like "The Great Replacement" and "white genocide", and the President is a contributing actor to that development.

Trump using eliminationist language like "invasion" and "infest" is no accident. That you would lay the blame for it on the "far left" is really twisted.

replies.author: @paulbrower
replies.text:
We need the seemingly-contradictory qualities of mental toughness and basic kindness. We need the capacity to recognize doing bad things to helpless or vulnerable people as abominations. We must repudiate bigotry when it insinuates itself into public life.

Nazi power, we must remember, began outside the state apparatus. The Weimar Republic was not persecuting Jews. Indeed, Weimar Germany was generally a good place in which to be a Jew. The garbage that emanated from Julius Streicher's vile rag was generally an object of mass derision. Private militias were the real danger -- and so they are in America today. 

Remember: law and order is the first civil right without which all enumerated rights are fantasy.

author: @outlander1924
text:
How many armed Americans defended the escaping slaves? How many armed Americans went after the government for Jim Crow? How many armed Americans show up at ICE facilities to free the kids in cages or stop the mass hysterectomies? How many armed Americans go after the government telling them to stop interfering and setting up coups in foreign countries? 
The problem is complacency and fascism. Arming complacent people won't do anything.

replies.author: @jesseberg3271
replies.text: Actually, _unarmed_ (white) Americans defended escaped slaves and freedmen on the streets of Boston.  Slave catchers came north, sometimes after a specific escapee, sometimes looking for whomever they could catch, and abolitionist gangs would beat them senseless if they tried to enter the city.  They could do this, not because they had guns, but because they were the majority, and they knew a Boston jury would never convict an abolitionist for assaulting a slave catcher.  That was what the Fugitive Slave Act was about, forcing Northern state governments to help and protect slave catchers.  As long as you have the law and the majority on your side, you don't need guns, and without them, guns aren't going to protect a minority.

author: @Ambious
text:
I only have one exception to this wonderful video: the quote "Everyone involved in the uprising was either killed or deported and then killed".
That is luckily not entirely true - my grandfather fought in the Uprising and was injured. He was smuggled out of the ghetto by the resistance to a German field hospital where he posed as a Nazi officer, with my grandmother posing as his nurse. They were discovered after a while, but fled and found shelter in the basement of the German embassy in Poland (which as it turns out hid Jews during the war!).
They both survived the war and the rebellion, and thanks to them I am here to tell this story.
