replies.author: @hektorsoininen
replies.text: Don't let this video fool you on the big topic here. The video is right with regards to Germany and their gun control policies of the time. But this particular example does not mean that gun control is a good thing. Everyone tends to casually look over the fact that Germany was an exception. One of the few tyrannies that allowed gun ownership for the majority. How about the Soviet Union, China and Iran? All of these are tyrannies who have taken away the rights of the population to own firearms.

replies.author: @vehx9316
replies.text:
@hektorsoininen 
You are looking at the end game of tyranny whereby the state had complete control over the populace. 

If you look back at the founding periods of the Soviet Union, China and Iran. They have plenty of weapons running around but they still supported the governments all the same. Thats because the tyrants and the authoritarians of today are actually the reactionaries of the past. Iran's current government revolted against the Shah who was quiet authoritarian himself, Lenin led the revolt against Tsarist Russia that was a monarchy at the time, the Chinese communist party defeated the Nationalist who were also authoritarian and have facists support as well. 

In short, having a well arm population would not have prevent these government rises because they were ridding the popular wave to power. Once they were in power however then they began systematically cutting off people and groups. 

The people of these countries willingly come UNDER authoritarian rule, not the other way around.

replies.author: @ChucksSEADnDEAD
replies.text:
@Caffeine_Addict_2020 oh no... I don't even have my degree yet and it's doable. For heat seeking you know what's the hardest part? It's literally the glass dome. You need a special kind of glass to narrow the spectrum of IR light that can get through but the rest is commonly available. In college we made a wheeled robot that would seek a lighter flame.
It's relatively simple, look up the Sidewinder story, it's a marvel of simplicity. A spinning reticle "chops" the signal with alternated opaque and transparent sections and a translucent section to normalize the signal. This gives you both the direction the seeker needs to turn and the relative angle to the boresight. Then the control of the missile wasn't even computerized, the missile would be steered by the seeker turning in the plane's direction. But that was with 1950's tech, these days you can put one of those cheap "system on a chip" boards and actually computerize the control and the seeker itself. Instead of using spin-scan reticles you could use mirrors to make a rosette seeker, and since the chip will have memory you can use it as a pseudo-imager and feed it code to allow it to reject flares.

Radar, that's slightly out of my league because I know very little about the field of communications so emitting radio waves isn't really my forte, but even freaking Matlab has a module to program solid state phased array. There's some tutorials on ranging radar online but it's more about a fixed tripod mounted radar that pings a range, then you move it sideways and ping it again, move, ping, etc until you get an almost "bird's eye view" of the place you're in, which is kinda neat but too simplistic and underpowered. Again it's not my forte so I don't even know the best way to output a powerful signal, but the principle could be employed on a mechanically moved antenna feeding the information into a computer. The tracking can be achieved through monopulse, I guess.

I know the mechanical and chemistry side, I'd need an electronics guy or else it would take me forever to learn all that shit. So you wouldn't need a team of 1000. If anything, the actual teams of "brains" working for Lockheed-Martin and Raytheon are probably limited to teams of 10-20 people on each project, and it's mostly for redundancies and having trainees around so they can take over the older guys' positions when they retire. And their job actually involves shit that it's going to be sold for half a million per unit because it's expected to work from -70潞C to +50潞C conditions, pass salt-water tests and it has to work with a huge degree of certainty and also there's generals who will obviously get jobs there when they retire from active duty so they charge the government five times what it should actually cost due to corruption. A "rebel" missile? Who cares about perfect reliability lol just launch 5 of them, if one of them hits you spent 5,000 dollars to bring down a 80+ million dollar plus plane and endanger a pilot that costs millions to train. You could actually do it with two people, and I'm kinda dumb so...

replies.author: @Caffeine_Addict_2020
replies.text:
Alright so you are a student, I was a student not too long ago, maybe I was a bit critical. As a student everything looked simple, I can sympathize. I'll point out a couple issues with your response. I don't know a ton about missiles so bear with me:

Building a car that moves in the direction of a flame is easy: on the ground you have a ton of stabilizing forces that you don't have in the air. For instance, the lateral force of the tires prevent the car from spinning out of control whereas in a missile you don't have that. In addition, a missile (thrust coming from the aft) is dynamically unstable so that problem is compounded. Basically, if you need to turn the missile the thruster is actively fighting against you. The algorithm needed to figure this out would probably take a team of people. 

You need a team to develop the engine. You need a team to develop the materials/shell of the aircraft. You need a team to develop the aerodynamics of the missile which, i'd argue, is the most difficult part. You need a team to develop the launcher (how do you launch the missile out of the tube without killing your man on the ground). You need a team to develop the computer brains - you mentioned MATLAB as a possible solution. MATLAB is a modeling tool. You never want to design a system that relies on MATLAB that you need to move faster than 2x a second, it's built for accuracy not speed. You need some sort of embedded chip, arduino's probably even too slow for what the missile would need to do. If you're developing your own antenna, you pretty much need a PHD for that; antenna's are notoriously difficult to design, it's basically wizardry. You'd need a team to develop the cooling and general thermodynamics. You'd need a team to develop all the electronics (launch, sensors, power supplies, etc.). You'd need a team to develop the payload/explosive system. You're right, maybe I overestimated the amount of people who would need to work on it, alot of these jobs could be done by 1 or a couple people. But it would take a long time, to develop it in, say, a year you'd need more people which would require managers and possibly managers of managers. Doubling the amount of people on a project doesn't halve the production time, it doesn't do close to that because there's always communication breakdowns between people working on things related toeach other

replies.author: @ChucksSEADnDEAD
replies.text:
@Caffeine_Addict_2020 "Building a car that moves in the direction of a flame is easy: on the ground you have a ton of stabilizing forces that you don't have in the air." - that's really not a point of contention. People build and fly aerodynamic objects in amateur fashion all the time. I was pointing out how the "brain" of the missile, which is the most complex part, isn't even that hard to make.

"a missile (thrust coming from the aft) is dynamically unstable so that problem is compounded" - there are literally dozens of videos here on youtube of people achieving stabilization of rockets through various means, including computerized ones.

"The algorithm needed to figure this out would probably take a team of people" - I'm sorry, what?
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IuikoTp6HyA
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qnUfsLCa8h8
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_kd64VE3A1c ("SpaceX style")
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZUgAvma_vBc
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lp4mH3qZfFs
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i7OqOj7GHuc
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NrkwjZ_23l8
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Zj2EwQLwmN4

Several individuals have managed it as a hobby....

*NOT TO MENTION THAT FOR EXAMPLE THE SIDEWINDER MISSILE IS INHERENTLY INSTABLE BY DESIGN* - Roll is prevented by rollerons and pitch and yaw "stabilization" is always being achieved through constant updates of the seeker. That is why the AIM-9 Sidewinder jitters along the way, it constantly fights instability created by its own control system. The original Sidewinder did not even have an algorithm as the missile control was purely electrical - putting a computer running code inside the missile in the 1950's would have been nearly impossible due to cost and size/weight.

"You need a team to develop the engine" - This isn't the Apollo program. Good thing that the basics have been covered by so many people: http://ddeville.com/derek/Qu8k.html and mind that the Qu8k is a high performance beast that achieved 121,000 ft VERTICALLY, which is completely overkill and over-engineered for a guerrilla surface-to-air missile. You're not trying to take out SR-71s, but targets of opportunity.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c8dovKYULEQ - this is a sugar powered rocket and the first stage got to 20,000 feet. Second stage got over 40,000. Omit the second stage and replace it by explosive payload. Lethal at 20,000 feet? Sounds good to me.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=959E5Oh7gPM - look at this absolute unit. I'm in awe at the size of this lad. It's a freaking wood structure and the motor casing seems to be steel tubing with end-cap and nozzle bolted on their respective end.

"You need a team to develop the materials/shell of the aircraft" -  Aluminum and fiberglass, the classics. The video I shown above has literally a rocket built out of wood and steel.

"You need a team to develop the aerodynamics of the missile which, i'd argue, is the most difficult part" - http://www.military-today.com/missiles/aim120_amraam.jpg one of the deadliest, highest-performing missiles in service and it's literally a 7 inch tube my dude.

"how do you launch the missile out of the tube without killing your man on the ground" - remote firing? I was actually thinking of a missile fired off the back of a truck with a support vehicle carrying the antenna so you could move around the country with the radar turned off to remain undetected, similar to the tactics used by the Serbs to shoot down the F-117 Nighthawk. But if we're talking about cheap, short range and man-portable IR seeking missiles yeah, line up 2-3 tubes several meters apart, a few kilometers away from an airstrip - when you expect a take off or landing, run into cover and have the firing trigger run off a long wire. If one explodes hopefully you set them up in a way that the explosion doesn't disturb the others and you got yourself an 80 million dollar crater right outside the airbase.

"You never want to design a system that relies on MATLAB that you need to move faster than 2x a second" - obviously it's for setting up the phased array. I don't think anyone would feed the data into matlab.

"You'd need a team to develop all the electronics (launch, sensors, power supplies, etc.)" - I'm sure one can get away with the use of off the shelf components. You know, like the amateur rockets I already posted video evidence of.

"You'd need a team to develop the payload/explosive system" - explosives ain't hard, though. The most complex part would be the proximity sensor. And even that can be made out of off the shelf components.

replies.author: @Caffeine_Addict_2020
replies.text:
Alright, so alot of your reply seems to center around hobby-rockets. But there is a large difference between hobby-rockets and a SAM. Mainly, hobbyists only need to get their rocket to go straight up, which is easy, and I will explain why:

1. If a rocket is going straight up, you don't care about turning, you don't care about changes in atmospheric pressure (dynamic and/or static, yes both are very important. This is why every aircraft has a pitot-tube on it, a very simple piece of technology that hasn't really changed since the beginning of aeronautics), you don't care about changes to aircraft mass due to loss in fuel. I'll break these down further:
a. turning: hobby-rockets don't need to turn, this is a huge deal. They can always assume gravity is below them and the code generally only needs to correct instability. With turning, you need to push the missile into an unstable mode and then stabilize it again. I don't think this is as simple as you think it is, especially since the missile would need to do this many times a second in order to be effective
b. pressure changes: the affect of your control surfaces (ie. the rollerons) changes based on your current altitude. Also, this changes with your current airspeed (not groundspeed) Again, not really a problem for rockets, and these are two important sensor reads
c. changes in mass: as you lose fuel from the rocket the behavior changes
These issues are probably not difficult to solve, but there's always some bullshit  problem that complicates these things
d. Missiles can't use solid propellant, i believe. A missile needs to throttle it's speed, you don't want it going full speed into a sharp turn. Throttling speed is another added complication. Also there may be added storage concerns for liquid fuel, like keeping it cooled before/during launch. You're probably not going to want to 
e. none of these rockets have payloads. Explosives are going to add significant weight to any rocket design. Explosives to blow up a jet weigh significantly more than a gopro

2. "This isn't the apollo program" in this point you miss the difference between rockets and missiles again. You're not making a sugar rocket, weight is too important. You're not catching a jet, or even helicopter using an inferior fuel like sugar. Again, a rocket that goes to 20k feet is not lethal at 20k feet, unless you get incredibly lucky and the jet just happens to end up at the exact spot that your rocket is ending up

3. materials: fair, but keep in mind that rockets don't undergo as many g's as a missile. undergoing a 90 degree turn at even half of rocket speed would probably destroy most wooden/fiberglass rockets. It's probably going to be steel or aluminum in the end. But I think you're right, I overcomplicated this point

4. "It's literally a 7 inch tube my dude" - aerodynamics don't work like that, this is a drastic oversimplifcation. Everything is designed very exactly, and if you don't have the specific locations of all the internals and dimensions of the control surfaces a picture is next to useless. You may know the general location of everything, but unlessyou have a model to measure out that's useless. Aerodynamics is a fickle bitch; moving a fuel tank 1 inch in any direction is going to drastically change the manueverability of an aircraft. There's a reason other countries buy american systems rather than develop their own, shits complicated yo

5. " missile fired off a truck" good points here, didn't think of that

6. I guess I misunderstood you then, I'm not sure what you meant by phased array. Can you clarify? Also good that you realized MATLAB sucks at real-time computations, I had a friend who was incredibly smart who decided to develop an arduino/MATLAB hybrid for a project and was shocked when its update speed sucked ass

7. Yes you can buy COTS products, the issue comes when combining them together. Making sure there's no noise on components (capacitive/inductive balancing or filters), making sure all your components are getting the correct voltage/current, making sure your servos are electrically isolated from your sensors/the rest of your system, etc etc. I'm sure an electrical engineer would have more to say, but no it's not just as simple as inserting components into a breadboard

8.  "eplosives ain't hard" true. But getting them to explode at the right time and just the idea of them existing in the missile complicate things beyond rockets

Alright I see I missed a couple ofyour points and I don't feel like renumbering so I'm just going to continue with:

9. "brain isn't complicated" again there are many, many more complications between missiles and rockets. In addition to what I explained above you also need to add in the ir sensing and calculating the velocity/acceleration of the craft. You're not aiming for where the aircraft is, but rather where it should be. This is not trivial, trust me. PID is another one of those witchcraft algorithms, that shit can get you lost in the weeds real quick. I've never designed a PID (PD,PI, or whatever combo) that I've been satisfied with. It's a challenge to make a decent one, I don't know how to make a great one

10. "stabilization" yes rocket stabilization is relatively easy, missile not as much. I enjoyed all the links, learned alot. I just want to point out that most of those did not use arduinos as you originally suggested, there was just that one guy. The reason being that arduinos were designed  for ease of use, not speed, not accuracy, not power, not GPIO, etc. Its a general purpose chip, and as such you rarely want to use it in a finalized product, almost anything is better. Also, arduinos vary alot based on where you buy them. I'm not even going to get into knockoffs, but OFFICIAL arduinos even vary based on when/which of the two split companies you buy them from. I've had SeVERE problems with them changing components out for no fucking reason - they changed a powersupply which completely fucked their Analog reference voltage, so sensor reads werejust bouncing all over the place

11."sidewinder stuff" I don't know anything about the original sidewinder, do you haveany sources on that? I find it hard to believe a missile was run purely analog that had any sort of seeking, but I could be wrong. A computer is very, very different from an embedded chip. Embedded chips have been around for a while

replies.author: @ChucksSEADnDEAD
replies.text:
@Caffeine_Addict_2020 1. a) b) c) it's important to understand that early missile command was very simplistic. For example the issue of air density changing with altitude was solved by ditching pressure sensors and rather than giving a set angle to the canards, they have them a set torque. This would mean less deflection in dense air, more deflection in thin air. I actually had to look this up and got results for the book "Sidewinder: Creative Missile Development at China Lake" by Ron Westrum and the team behind the first Sidewinder actually had 30 scientists/engineers and 12 technicians which is pretty impressive considering that today a team basically only needs to use the existing literature and they had to solve never-seen problems with 1950's technology. The same book also states they wanted to make the missile as "independent" of aerodynamics as possible.
d) You can use solid fuel and oxidizer in a hybrid system that allows you to throttle. (pretty long but there's a sequence showing how they built the hybrid engine https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BJppeRWSD94) I don't know what would happen to commercial Nitrous Oxide sources if they were being used in missiles and the synthesis seems to not be worth it and I don't know if straight oxygen can be used. But that's not really important because many missiles do actually use solid fuel. Most missiles do not use any throttle, they typically fire everything they have for a few seconds and then coast. That's why pilots are trained in defeating missiles kinetically. While ECM, chaff, flares, etc are extremely well-developed systems they're not silver bullets (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fzsbG4WX2R8) and it's preferable to use maneuvers that waste kinetic energy and prevent the missile from even getting near. You control the burn properties with the shape of the grain and that's it.
e) Very true which is why I think the performance of those amateur rockets are impressive. Even if I cut performance in half, it could still catch a plane in some phases of flight.

2. I'm kinda putting an emphasis on vertical performance because the intention is track planes as they pass overheat and try to make a launch that basically tries to "meet" the plane on its way, not try to make a "horizontal chase". It wouldn't be luck, just observation and patience. Besides, stealth is a thing now and planes will be shaped to minimize their signature in the next decades but the bottom of the plane will always be relatively flat and give the most reflection.

4. Well, shit is complicated because i) everything has to be certified to the umpteenth degree even to the smallest part - you can't simply purchase bolts at a hardware store - there's security clearances involved, etc ii) For example NATO systems have to be compatible in a way that allows a French airplane with a Swedish radar to detect a target for a German aircraft firing an American missile so things tend to get centralized to the major arms manufacturers iii) we're talking about national defense and things have to be very reliable. So of course that most countries will not give this job to college kids when a malfunction on a missile can kill personnel in case of catastrophic failure or even worse, allow an enemy to pass through the faulty defenses and destroy a factory or a military base. But when you're firing a thousand dollar tube for a chance of burning several millions of dollars, a "college level" project is fine.

6. Basically there's the "analog" antenna which sends a beam, typically a metallic structure with a parabolic shape. A phased array is several emitters on a flat dish, and by phasing the emitters you add the emission in the direction you want while cancelling the signal in directions you don't want it to go. Instead of pointing the antenna at what you want to beam the flat dish can manipulate the beam to point in the intended direction without moving. I don't even know if one could purchase the actual small emitters or make them, my point was that even high-tech stuff like complicated radar control can be modeled through software.

7. That's definitely true but even simple projects have issues such as isolating signals from noise. There's challenges, but people more used to electronics can do it.

8. The fuse can be a challenge. Thinking about it, I think the best bet would be a laser proximity sensor with a small radar sensor backup because even though it increases the complexity  to manage two sensor types it would be a massive waste to have a missile work perfectly and then get a near miss that doesn't explode. To make sure it goes off one could have the detonator control linked to multiple blasting caps to make sure there is no dud.

9. and 11. I'll quote wikipedia: "The Sidewinder is not guided on the actual position recorded by the detector, but on the change in position since the last sighting. So if the target remained at 5 degrees left between two rotations of the mirror, the electronics would not output any signal to the control system. Consider a missile fired at right angles to its target; if the missile is flying at the same speed as the target, it should "lead" it by 45 degrees, flying to an impact point far in front of where the target was when it was fired. If the missile is traveling four times the speed of the target, it should follow an angle about 11 degrees in front. In either case, the missile should keep that angle all the way to interception, which means that the angle that the target makes against the detector is constant. It was this constant angle that the Sidewinder attempted to maintain. This "proportional pursuit" system is very easy to implement, yet it offers high-performance lead calculation almost for free and can respond to changes in the target's flight path,[7] which is much more efficient and makes the missile "lead" the target." -https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proportional_navigation-- --- "A rather simple hardware implementation of this guidance law can be found in early AIM-9 Sidewinder missiles. These missiles use a rapidly rotating parabolic mirror as a seeker. Simple electronics detect the directional error the seeker has with its target (an IR source), and apply a moment to this gimballed mirror to keep it pointed at the target. Since the mirror is in fact a gyroscope it will keep pointing at the same direction if no external force or moment is applied, regardless of the movements of the missile. The voltage applied to the mirror while keeping it locked on the target is then also used (although amplified) to deflect the control surfaces that steer the missile, thereby making missile velocity vector rotation proportional to line of sight rotation. Although this does not result in a rotation rate that is always exactly proportional to the LOS-rate (which would require a constant airspeed), this implementation is equally effective." - from what I am reading I don't even think the early Sidewinders even had a way of measuring closing rate. The important part seems to be this: *the voltage applied to the mirror while keeping it locked on the target is then also used (although amplified) to deflect the control surfaces that steer the missile, thereby making missile velocity vector rotation proportional to line of sight rotation*

The Sparrow, which was a semi-active radar guided missile, could at least estimate the closing rate from the Doppler shift.

10. "they changed a powersupply which completely fucked their Analog reference voltage, so sensor reads werejust bouncing all over the place" - that's a problem I wasn't even aware of, thanks for the insight.

More information about IR-seekers:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infrared_homing#Scanning_patterns_and_modulation (describes the early spin, conical and crossed array sensors)
https://basicsaboutaerodynamicsandavionics.wordpress.com/category/uncategorized/ (Ctlr+F for "Infrared Sensors" and go to the first mention, it pretty much gives the basic rundown of how sensors work, from the early chopped reticle spin scan to the modern infrared imaging arrays)

replies.text:
Why is there debunking needed? The argument is completely stupid to begin with. IQ is an artificial measurement for the ability to solve complex problems. Many groups in Africa have slightly to much less (often caused by malnutrition) IQ on average while Asians have more than Europeans. But what does that mean in the end? Nothing because IQ has very little impact on reality (not everyone with a high IQ is productive, rich, happy or any other attribute you want to measure and vice versa). And in the end what is the utility of people? An economist wouldnt say it is his wealth or productivity but his own ultitly aka happiness and that is not connected positively with high IQs.
Other than that - isnt one of the right wing ideas that the individiuum is more important than the group? So why judge groups based on an artificial number and then apply this to an individuum? It makes no sense...

author: @impartscreativestudio6789
text:
You, sir, are a wonderfully rational human being. A rare thing these days. 
My father fought in World War II for America. He was a paratrooper in the Signal Corps. He was also a major. He and his troops were dropped, do to a navigational error, in the wrong area. It was an area of heavy German troop movements. It was also shortly after Eisenhower had refused to surrender unconditionally to Hitler. Hitler had declared that he would then take all American officers that he captured and place them in death camps with the Jews. When my father and his platoon were dropped, they were dropped into a thickly wooded forest. Of course, the result was that they were all tangled up in the trees. Before they could free themselves a German Patrol came by and proceeded to shoot the entire platoon dead with the exception of my father, who of course was a major. My father was then transported to Dachau. Before the war ended, my father was moved two more times to Treblinka and Auschwitz, he was something of a troublemaker, constantly trying to escape constantly trying to help others. He did manage to help a German woman and her three daughters to escape. He had intended to escape with them but something went wrong and in order to cover their escape he led the German guards on a merry chase finally allowing himself to be recaptured. 
My father could have instilled me with a deep hatred of all German people for the treatment that he received in those death camps. Instead, he went to great pains to teach me the difference between your average German citizen and a Nazi. After the war my father volunteered during the Reformation and was sent to Buchen as a judge Magistrate. When he arrived there the townspeople were starving because the Allied troops had locked up all of the towns weapons and refused to allow the people of the town to hunt to feed themselves. The first thing he did was to go to that to the armory, break the lock and allow the people to have their weapons back. There were other things that he did to help them, but mostly he was decent to them. When my father passed away in 1976, the people of Buchan printed a beautiful Memorial article on the first page of the town's newspaper. Later, after my father passed, I met the youngest daughter of the woman my father had helped to escape. She showed me her tattoo and told me the story of how she, her mother and her sisters had escaped from that death camp. This was the first time I heard this story as my father refused to talk in any detail about that time. With tears in her eyes and shaky voice, she told me that she owed her very existence to my father and she was very upset that she didn't find him before he died to thank him personally. I tell you all of this so that you understand the depth of my feelings when I say to you: thank you.
I am subscribing to your channel.

author: @Snommelp
text: I'm so happy that you shared that timeline. You're absolutely right; given what these same people feel about violence in response to hate speech, the first "proper" time for an armed Jewish response to German oppression would have been Kristallnacht, and by then it was far too late. And even that statement requires an asterisk, because Kristallnacht was justified as being a response to violence. If you try to create a coherent and consistent argument from the totality of Carson's or Shapiro's statements, then you have to imagine that European Jews would have been perfectly docile citizens right up to the moment they were taken to the trains, at which point they would have all grabbed their rifles and fended off the German military, ending the war and the Holocaust in a single day.

replies.author: @dfmrcv862
replies.text:
That's... not the argument. The argument is that if you disarm a population, they are easier to control. The moment to rebel wouldn't be "when they're getting taken from their homes" but when they are being disarmed because you can't just steal someone from their homes unless they are disarmed and you know they are disarmed, OR, you are willing to sacrifice many lives in order to get that person. 

If the Jewish population of Germany had been armed to the teeth, you better believe the Nazis would have had a harder time of things as they did in France, Poland, and Belarus. Like... even if it didn't "stop" the Holocaust, having a homegrown insurrection would have been such a thorn on Germany's side it would have impacted their war effort and maybe even end World War 2 sooner.

replies.author: @c0nd0rd4myt
replies.text:
@dfmrcv862 It's actually precisely the argument. Bens Carson and Shapiro ARE saying that the holocaust could have been prevented (or at the very least, greatly reduced) if only the Jews had guns.

In any of the quotations hear in the video, you will not find "control" listed once.

Also, Krytsalnacht happened before the invasion of France, Poland, or the Battle of Brtain, by years. It seems highly unlikely that a Jewish resistance would have survived that long, let alone been successful. There were 800,000 Jews in Germany, including women, children, and the elderly. By Contrast, the Wehrmacht had a total force strength of 15 Million. Nearly 20 to 1 to odds, to say nothing of the massive difference in weaponry at their disposal.

This would have been nothing short of a bloodbath.

replies.author: @Snommelp
@dfmrcv862
replies.text:
@c0nd0rd4myt the reason "control" isn't in any of the quotes presented is because There Arrows cut them. 

And say of those 800,000 100,000 had guns and 45,000 chose to rebel and fight... Remember the hundreds of accounts of tiny resistance forces holding back the German advance with noticing but small arms?

Maybe it wouldn't have lasted the years until the invasion of Poland but it certainly would have brought more attention to Nazi Germany and been a warning to Jews elsewhere. 

 Had the 800,000 Jews taken up arms and resisted you better believe the holocaust would have been greatly reduced in capability.

replies.author: @dfmrcv862
replies.text:
@Snommelp Now, while its true the Nazis didn't care much for keeping Jews alive it was vital that they did. Remember, the German population was kept pretty in the dark about the Holocaust not just because of potential outrage but because of the fury that would come from people realizing the vital resources to win the war were being prioritized on industrializing murder even if they hated the people being murdered.

Even still, Jewish resistance had they all been armed would have realistically deterred or slowed down the holocaust to the point it wouldn't have been necessarily as destructive given Germany's limited time to win World War 2.

The propagansits would have loved an armed Jewish rebellion, because now they don't need to talk in euphemism. They really are trying to destroy the country, and they're doing it in public. This not only justified the use of the Wehrmacht to suppress the rebellion, but it also easily turns the German people to turn against the Jews. The Nazi Government was very popular at that time, especially compared to the Weimar Republic.

replies.author: @dfmrcv862
replies.text: @c0nd0rd4myt so you went from "it won't work" to "it will work so well Germans will feel more justified in persecuting them"?

replies.author: @c0nd0rd4myt
replies.text: @dfmrcv862 The Warsaw Uprising led to 15,000 Resistance members dying on top of 150,000-250,000 Polish civilian deaths, compared to about the deaths of 2,000 German soldiers, in the span of 62 days. The Jews within the Warsaw Ghetto were stubborn, and impossibly brave, but there's no way one could look at the situation and see it as a successful resistance campaign.

replies.author: @c0nd0rd4myt
replies.text: @dfmrcv862 Not hardly. I'm saying that the Nazi's would leverage an opportunity to make the Jewish Rebellion look like an existential threat, to pit German citizens against the Jews, in order to justify the brutal measures that they would have wanted to take anyway.

replies.author: @dfmrcv862
replies.text: @c0nd0rd4myt the estimate of German deaths is off. It was closer to twenty thousand dead or missing with 2000 *confirmed* deaths.

replies.author: @dfmrcv862
replies.text: @c0nd0rd4myt And you're assuming the Germans would be entirely alright with it. Even if they were, the resistance could do enough damage if we look at the Warsaw uprising as an example of how Germans dealt with things.

replies.author: @c0nd0rd4myt
replies.text: @dfmrcv862 What evidence do you have to show that they would have a problem with it? The Nazi Regime was highly supported by the German People, and Antisemitism was the norm throughout the western world. Even putting aside the plan to eliminate Jews, the fact alone that they would be trying to destroy the government that saved Germany from the terrible Weimar Republic would make them the enemy in the eyes of most Germans.

replies.author: @c0nd0rd4myt
replies.text: @dfmrcv862 It could? Based on what facts? This is an organization that behind closed doors always wanted nothing short of Jewish extermination, you really think some grandma's with guns is going to get in their way?

replies.author: @dfmrcv862
@c0nd0rd4myt
replies.text: @dfmrcv862 You're forgetting the fact that the 40 guys at the border still lost.

replies.author: @dfmrcv862
replies.text: @c0nd0rd4myt Not at all. They did their duty and helped stop the Nazi regime.

replies.author: @c0nd0rd4myt
replies.text:
@dfmrcv862 Stalled, would be more accurate.
It wasn't until the Battle of Britain that anyone successfully "Stopped" the Nazi's.

replies.author: @dfmrcv862
replies.text:
@c0nd0rd4myt "Stalled" Oxford definition: stop or cause to stop making progress.

Okay, it was temporary, but the point is that a group of guys with bolt action rifles stopped one of the most powerful armies in the world for a short time, cementing that an armed civilian population can and have put dents in even some of most powerful armies in human history.

replies.author: @c0nd0rd4myt
@dfmrcv862
replies.text:
@c0nd0rd4myt No, I claimed a Jewish uprising could have had a major effect in the war and the holocaust. You're the one that keeps changing topics. You go "it always fails" until literally shown the opposite, so you claim "just because it sees some success doesn't mean it works" until again shown that the point is that it had success, where you go right back to arguing that "it always fails".

You're mot and bailing and it's getting quite tiresome. 

Tell you what... you admit tyrants disarm their population and that an armed population is harder to control so that we can be done with this, I'll admit that it is incredibly *difficult* for armed civilians on their own to defeat an entire military in a one V. one scenario.

Cool?

replies.author: @c0nd0rd4myt
replies.text:
@dfmrcv862 incredibly difficult is being  charitable. Anecdotal examples of success do not reverse the larger narratives of failure.

I'm not aware of one case of armed civilians having a successful rebellion or insurrection that didn't have help from the outside (French helping the colonists, Chinese helping the VIetcong, American CIA supporting the Mujhadeen).

Is it remotely possible that an Armed Rebellion of Jewish Citizens could have stopped the Holocaust and made a severe dent in the overall war effort? ya, maybe. 

That still doesn't make what Shapiro or Carson say correct; both of who speak with near total certainty that a rebellion would have been successful.

That's the bottom line up front: those two are still wrong, and the video is still correct in pointing out exactly how and why they're wrong.

replies.author: @dfmrcv862
replies.text:
@c0nd0rd4myt Geez, you can't even concede that, can you?

French Revolution, Russian Revolution, the October Revolution, the 1945 battle of Athens, 90% of the Haitian revolution, the Mexican Revolution (both of them), most of Latin America's wars for independence, need I go on?

author: @endempires
text:
I think the idea behind the 2nd amendment requires more than just guns. The German people were armed but supported a tyrannical government. The 2nd amendment is ideal when the entire populace is armed as a deterrent to a government overstepping its bounds; it goes hand in hand with a small government. I think it presupposes that a big government is a step away from tyrannical which is sort of true.

Out of the right wing voices Shapiro is probably my favorite but I like to balance my ideological input. Good video, good reply to the argument, and good that you don't overstep into "this means the 2nd amendment is useless". Might subscribe, this is the first I saw.

replies.text: Excatly! The 2 amendment only works if all the people rise up as a whole against an openly tyrannical government. And even then the chances of success are not high. But no dictatorship is dumb enough to just declare itself the enemy of the people. In fact most of them don't even see themselves as such
